articles.headline: Rise in Pill Abuse Forces New Look at U.S. Drug Fight
articles.snippet: The shift toward painkillers is forcing policy makers to re-examine the expensive strategy of trying to stop illegal drugs from entering the United States.
articles.abstract: The shift toward painkillers is forcing policy makers to re-examine the expensive strategy of trying to stop illegal drugs from entering the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — America’s drug problem is shifting from illicit substances like cocaine to abuse of prescription painkillers, a change that is forcing policy makers to re-examine the long and expensive strategy of trying to stop illegal drugs from entering the United States.
articles.byline: By Damien Cave and Michael S. Schmidt

articles.headline: U.S. Tightens Security for Economic Data
articles.snippet: Fearing leaks to high-speed traders, the government is overhauling its “lockup room,” where news media wait to hear new inflation numbers, jobless rates and other critical information.
articles.abstract: Fearing leaks to high-speed traders, the government is overhauling its “lockup room,” where news media wait to hear new inflation numbers, jobless rates and other critical information.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Tuesday morning at precisely 8:30, after a 10-second countdown synchronized to the Naval Observatory’s atomic clock, a Labor Department official flipped a master switch in the agency’s battened-down pressroom and computers blurted out the monthly Consumer Price Index.

articles.headline: A Yahoo Search Calls Up a Chief From Google
articles.snippet: Marissa Mayer, one of the top executives at Google, will be the next C.E.O. of Yahoo, making her one of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley and corporate America.
articles.abstract: Marissa Mayer, one of the top executives at Google, will be the next C.E.O. of Yahoo, making her one of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley and corporate America.
articles.lead_paragraph: 9:06 p.m. | Updated Marissa Mayer, one of the top executives at Google, will be the next chief of Yahoo, making her one of the most prominent women in Silicon Valley and corporate America.
articles.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Evelyn M. Rusli

articles.headline: In Nod to New Era, Microsoft Unveils Touch-Based Version of Office
articles.snippet: Microsoft redesigned its Office applications to take advantage of trends like touch-based devices, social networking and cloud computing.
articles.abstract: Microsoft redesigned its Office applications to take advantage of trends like touch-based devices, social networking and cloud computing.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For many people, Microsoft programs like Word and Excel are about as cutting edge as a shovel — tools that get the job done, but do not quicken the pulse the way an iPad or an Xbox does.

articles.headline: Cuba Hits Wall in 2-Year Push to Expand the Private Sector
articles.snippet: Nearly two years into an economic overhaul aimed at bolstering private enterprise, new import duties and dogmatic fears are threatening the Cuban government’s stated goals.
articles.abstract: Nearly two years into an economic overhaul aimed at bolstering private enterprise, new import duties and dogmatic fears are threatening the Cuban government’s stated goals.
articles.lead_paragraph: HAVANA — Nearly two years into the Cuban government’s economic overhaul aimed at slashing public payrolls and bolstering private enterprise, the reforms have slowed so much that many Cuban entrepreneurs and intellectuals are questioning the aging leadership’s ability — or will — to reshape one of the world’s last Communist systems and shift nearly half of the island’s output to private hands.

articles.headline: In Tiny Bean, India’s Dirt-Poor Farmers Strike Gas-Drilling Gold
articles.snippet: Profits from raising guar, a hard bean that is crucial in the drilling process called hydraulic fracturing, have improved the lives of poor farmers in northwestern India.
articles.abstract: Profits from raising guar, a hard bean that is crucial in the drilling process called hydraulic fracturing, have improved the lives of poor farmers in northwestern India.
articles.lead_paragraph: LORDI, India — Sohan Singh’s shoeless children have spent most of their lives hungry, dirty and hot. A farmer in a desert land, Mr. Singh could not afford anything better than a mud hut and a barely adequate diet for his family.

articles.headline: Mormons’ First Families Rally Behind Romney
articles.snippet: Descendants of Mormons who made the great trek to Utah in the 1840s have turned out in strength to back Mitt Romney.
articles.abstract: Descendants of Mormons who made the great trek to Utah in the 1840s have turned out in strength to back Mitt Romney.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — In the mid-1800s, newly converted families from across the United States and Europe gathered in the growing Mormon town of Nauvoo, Ill., to help their prophet, Joseph Smith, build a New Jerusalem.

articles.headline: Merchants Considering Credit Card Surcharges
articles.snippet: Businesses weighed next moves after a deal that allows merchants to offer discounts to those paying with cash, and to impose fees on those using plastic.
articles.abstract: Businesses weighed next moves after a deal that allows merchants to offer discounts to those paying with cash, and to impose fees on those using plastic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Starting this week, prices are 2 percent lower on ScanMyPhotos.com. At the grocer Kroger, executives are contemplating charging two prices for groceries — a lower price when shoppers pay with cash, and a higher one when they use a credit card. And at restaurants across the country, owners are weighing the wisdom — or lack of it — of a surcharge on bills paid with credit cards.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Stephanie Strom

articles.headline: Mayer Hopes to Brighten User Experience at Yahoo
articles.snippet: Marissa Mayer’s challenge will be to resuscitate a moribund company and to avoid the fate of so many other experienced executives who have run Yahoo.
articles.abstract: Marissa Mayer’s challenge will be to resuscitate a moribund company and to avoid the fate of so many other experienced executives who have run Yahoo.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It is as if there is a revolving door to the executive suite at Yahoo. So many have filed in and out over the years: Terry Semel, Jerry Yang, Carol Bartz and Scott Thompson. On Tuesday, Marissa Mayer, a Google executive, will join the company as its fifth full-time chief executive in five years.

articles.headline: Cautious on Growth, Bernanke Offers No Hint of New Action
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve chairman said the central bank was seeking greater clarity on the health of the recovery as it weighed the need for a new round of economic stimulus.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve chairman said the central bank was seeking greater clarity on the health of the recovery as it weighed the need for a new round of economic stimulus.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, said Tuesday that the Fed was seeking greater clarity about the health of the recovery, suggesting that officials were not ready to approve another round of stimulus.

articles.headline: Gloomy Forecast for States, Even if Economy Rebounds
articles.snippet: Long after the economy rebounds, states will face financial problems that include rising health care costs and underfunded pensions, a task force of budget experts said.
articles.abstract: Long after the economy rebounds, states will face financial problems that include rising health care costs and underfunded pensions, a task force of budget experts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The fiscal crisis for states will persist long after the economy rebounds as they confront rising health care costs, underfunded pensions, ignored infrastructure needs, eroding revenues and expected federal budget cuts, according to a report issued here Tuesday by a task force of respected budget experts.
articles.byline: By Mary Williams Walsh and Michael Cooper
